items.description: As the larva grows, it consumes living tissue and can cause damage to the muscle. After the larva is removed and the wound heals, a significant scar may be left behind.
items.title: Tissue Damage and Scarring

items.description: The developing larva creates a firm, painful, and itchy lump (known as a "warble") under the skin. A person may feel sensations of movement or sharp, stabbing pain as the larva moves or anchors itself with its spines.
items.title: Pain and Discomfort

items.description: A local inflammatory response with redness, swelling, and a serous, bloody, or pus-like discharge from a central breathing hole (punctum) is common.
items.title: Inflammation and Discharge

items.description: Shiny black or very dark brown with a large, rounded abdomen.

items.description: Often has red and white bands or spots on the sides of the abdomen.

items.description: A red or orange hourglass shape on the underside of the abdomen, which can sometimes appear as two separate triangles or be faded.
items.title: Female black _widow Markings

items.description: Young children, the very ill, and the elderly are at higher risk for severe complications and potentially fatal outcomes.
items.title: Risk factors

items.description: May feel like a simple pinprick and is often not noticed immediately.
items.title: Initial bite

items.description: A dull muscle ache can spread throughout the body.
items.title: Within hours

items.description: In rare cases, a black _widow bite can cause cardiac problems like heart inflammation, but this is usually reversible with treatment.
items.title: Cardiac issues

items.description: Can develop, including severe muscle cramps, abdominal pain, sweating, nausea, vomiting, and high blood pressure.
items.title: Serious symptoms

items.description: Call 911 or go to the emergency room immediately if you experience any of the following, especially if you are a child or an older adult: Severe pain or worsening whole-body symptomsDifficulty breathingHeart palpitations or racing pulseSigns of infection (fever or yellow discharge)Severe headache or vision problems
items.title: When to seek emergency care

items.description: Most healthy individuals recover fully within 24 to 48 hours, though milder symptoms can last for several weeks.
items.title: Recovery time

items.description: The bite area may swell, become painful, and develop redness or numbness.
items.title: Within an hour

items.description: There is a risk of secondary infection if the bite is not properly cleaned.
items.title: Infection risk

items.description: A signature trait is their large, medium-sized ears which are broad at the base and carried erect and parallel when alert.
items.title: Ears

items.description: They have a strong, athletic build with a body that is typically longer than it is tall. The back can be straight (common in working lines) or sloped toward the hindquarters (often seen in show lines).
items.title: Build

items.description: The German Shepherd has a dense double coat to protect them in various weather. The outer coat is typically medium-length, dense, and straight or slightly wavy. Common colors include black and tan/red, black and cream, sable, and solid black.
items.title: Coat and Color

items.description: Males stand 24 to 26 inches tall at the shoulder and typically weigh between 65 to 90 pounds. Females are slightly smaller, standing 22 to 24 inches and weighing 50 to 70 pounds.
items.title: Size

items.description: The head is proportionate to the body, tapering to a strong, square-cut muzzle with a black nose and powerful jaws. They have medium-sized, dark, almond-shaped eyes that convey a keen and intelligent expression.
items.title: Head and Face

items.description: They possess a long, bushy tail that hangs in a slight saber-like curve when at rest.
items.title: Tail

items.description:
You should seek immediate medical care after any dog bite that breaks the skin. Prompt medical evaluation is critical to prevent severe complications, including

Uncontrollable bleeding.

A deep or large wound.

Bites on the hands, face, neck, or feet.

Signs of infection like spreading redness, swelling, increasing pain, or pus.

If you are unsure of the dog's vaccination status or have not had a tetanus shot in the last 5-10 years.
items.title: Details

items.description: A rapidly spreading bacterial skin infection caused by bacteria likePasteurella multocida, which is common in dog saliva.
items.title: Cellulitis

items.description: The combination of physical injury and emotional distress can lead to depression.
items.title: Psychological Effects:Depression

items.description: These are the most common health concerns.
items.title: Bacterial Infections

items.description: Common bacterial infections that can lead to abscesses, joint swelling, and fever.
items.title: StaphandStrep Infections

items.description: The force of the bite can crush tissue and, in severe cases, break bones, especially in smaller victims like children or in sensitive areas like the hands and feet.
items.title: Crushing Injuries and Bone Fractures

items.description: If an infection enters the bloodstream and spreads throughout the body, it can lead to sepsis, a life-threatening condition requiring immediate medical attention.
items.title: Sepsis

items.description: The deep nature of the wounds can sever or damage nerves, tendons, and muscles, potentially leading to permanent loss of function, sensation, or chronic pain in the affected area.
items.title: Nerve and Tendon Damage

items.description: Severe bites often require stitches or reconstructive surgery, which can result in permanent scarring or disfigurement.
items.title: Scarring and Disfigurement

items.description: German Shepherds have strong jaws (bite force can exceed 238 pounds per square inch) capable of inflicting deep puncture wounds and significant soft tissue damage.
items.title: Deep Puncture Wounds and Lacerations

items.description: The bacteria that cause tetanus can enter the body through a puncture wound. A tetanus shot booster may be needed if it has been more than five years since your last vaccination.
items.title: Tetanus

items.description: This is a severe, almost always fatal viral disease once symptoms appear. The risk depends on the dog's vaccination status and local rabies prevalence. If the dog is a stray or unvaccinated, post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is necessary.
items.title: Rabies

items.description: Victims may experience vivid flashbacks and intense fear.
items.title: Psychological Effects:Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)

items.description: Developing a lasting fear of dogs, which can impact daily life and social interactions.
items.title: Psychological Effects:Anxiety and Fear

items.description: Dog mouths harbor numerous bacteria, and any bite that breaks the skin is at risk of infection.
items.title: Infectious Diseases and Complications

items.description: A rare but potentially fatal infection, especially for individuals with weakened immune systems or who are asplenic (lacking a spleen). Symptoms can progress rapidly to sepsis, organ failure, andgangrene.
items.title: Capnocytophaga canimorsusinfection

items.description: including hives and anaphylaxis (in rare cases)
items.title: Allergic reactions

items.title: Skin Irritation

items.description: Stress, anxiety, and insomnia due to the discomfort and fear associated with bed bug infestations.
items.title: Psychological Impact

items.description: Scratching the bites can break the skin and increase the risk of bacterial or fungal infections.
